title: Iran bans chess champion from national team after she REFUSED to wear a hijab
text:
Iran bans chess champion from national team after she REFUSED to wear a hijab Iran bans chess champion from national team after she REFUSED to wear a hijab A TEENAGE girl has been banned from Iran’s national chess team for refusing to wear a hijab. PUBLISHED: 22:27, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 | UPDATED: 22:38, Tue, Feb 21, 2017 FACEBOOK/ GETTY Dorsa Derakhshani was kicked off the Iran national chess team for not wearing a hijab 
Dorsa Derakhshani, an 18-year-old grandmaster, has been kicked out of the national team and can no longer play in domestic tournaments. 
Iranian authorities were outraged after the teenager played without a traditional headscarf at the Tradewise Gibraltar Chess Festival. 
Hijabs became compulsory headgear for women after the 1979 revolution. Related articles Our national interests have priority over everything Mehrdad Pahlevanzadeh 
Mehrdad Pahlevanzadeh, head of the Iranian Chess Federation, said the organisation will “seriously deal” with Dorsa’s actions. 
Her brother Borna, 15, has also been banned from the team after he played a chess match against Israel. 
Mr Pahlevanzadeh said: “Unfortunately, what shouldn’t have happened has happened. 
“Our national interests have priority over everything. 
“As a first step, these two will be denied entry to all tournaments taking place in Iran, and, in the name of Iran, they will no longer be allowed the opportunity to be present on the national team.” 
The siblings are yet to comment publicly on the ban. FACEBOOK Dorsa Derakhshani did not wear a hijab during a tournament in Gibraltar FACEBOOK The teenager was punished for playing without a traditional headscarf 
Islamic codes of behaviour and dress are strictly enforced in the Middle Eastern country, with sports long affected by the regime’s strict rules. 
Morality police have been known to raid clothes shops selling Western garments with women expected to cover their heads, wear trousers and a long sleeved coat or tunic that reaches to the mid-thigh or knee in Iran. GETTY An Iranian policewoman warns a woman about her clothing and hair during a crackdown in 2007 GETTY Morality police in Iran are known to launch crackdowns on dress Could this be the hijab collection Debenhams plans to sell? Mon, February 13, 2017 Hijabs will be sold in UK department stores after retailer Debenhams announced it would become the first to stock the Islamic dress as part of a new range of Muslim clothing. London-based clothing brand Aab, which is behind the line, describes itself as selling ‘contemporary modest wear’ for women. aab Collection 1 of 12 
The regime’s Revolutionary Guards Force are known to carry out suprise inspections and raids across Iran. 
Women who fail to veil themselves correctly are reprimanded in public. Related articles
